scenes.location: MARLO AND DREW'S HOUSE, (SARAH'S ROOM) SARAH'S ROOM

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Hold still, Jonah. She moves to the other side, running the brush down the o arm, gently pressing the soft bristles into his skin. MARLO (CONT’D) There we go. Let’s do feet now. Sit down. Jonah sits down. He casually grabs his crotch and holds o MARLO (CONT’D) Do you need to go to the bathroom? Jonah continues holding himself.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Just being your own best friend, huh? Jonah nods blithely.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. She resumes brushing, gently running the bristles over th soles of Jonah’s BARE FEET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo heads into another bedroom, equally small but more feminine. SARAH, 8, is sitting at a small desk, looking irritated with her homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost done here?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Let me see. (reading) “In Chapter Three of I Hate Rules, Katie Kazoo decides that there should be no more rules at school. What are the consequences?”

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Things get out of hand, don’t they?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: How about George? He ate ten desserts and then what happened? Sarah plays with her hair, distracted.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not going to write this for you, Sares. Sarah puts her head down on the desk dramatically. She BA it twice. Marlo stares at her daughter wearily. Sarah bangs her head a THIRD TIME for good measure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo walks into the kitchen. It’s small and there are a boxes of assorted ENERGY BARS propped open on the already cluttered counters. Marlo Grabs two LUNCH BOXES off the counter. Then, she reaches for her PHONE and plugs a set EARBUDS into it. She picks a song. MUSIC UP: “Blue” by the Jayhawks. As the music plays, Marlo begins makes two LUNCHES for Jo and Sarah. Finally, an escape from the children, even if she’s still servicing them. She places two different sandwiches into plastic bento b She pours Goldfish crackers from a Costco-sized container into two of the compartments. She cuts on the diagonal. Marlo’s husband DREW enters. He’s a slightly nerdy softwa engineer in a Doctor Who T-shirt. Marlo pulls out her earbuds. Her private moment is over abruptly. Without missing a beat, Drew begins filling Thermoses and slicing the green tops off the strawberries. Marlo and Dr are a well-oiled machine. Their childcare routines are choreographed like ballet.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Jonah’s finally down. Jesus, it’s like trying to kill the head vampire.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Did you bring Sarah her inhaler?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Yeah. Did you, uh, brush Jonah?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Roger wilco. Hey, don’t forget, we're going to my brother’s for dinner tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Ugh. Craig hates me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Craig doesn’t hate you. He just hangs out with i-bankers all day, so his default setting is “ass.”

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: You think he’1ll respect me more now that I got a promotion?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: No. (then) But, I bet he can’t wait to show us his new Tesla! They switch to stupid, deep “bro” voices to imitate Craig

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: “It’s sick, dude!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “It’s soooo sick! Look how I plug it in.” They bond briefly over making fun of Craig. MARLO (CONT’D) “I don’t just look cool, I’m single- handedly saving the planet.”

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: “You're welcome, Earth.” Marlo chucks a mayonnaise-covered knife into the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wet spring morning in Rye, New York. Marlo’s dented Hon Fit rolls into the parking lot of ST. VITUS ELEMENTARY SCHOOL. INT. MARLO’S CAR - DAY Marlo is behind the wheel. Jonah and Sarah are strapped i booster seats in the back of the car.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: This is not our lot.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Go to the other parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: The other parking lot’s full, honey. We have to park here today.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (groaning) Not again...

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Jonah, I have to meet with Mrs. Bell in... (checking) negative three minutes. Please let’s just park here.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Other lot! Other lot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah, don’t. Jonah begins KICKING THE SEAT and SCREAMING. He can’t han any disruption to his routine. He melts down.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: No! No! Noooooo!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (distressed) Mom! Make him stop!

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: (screaming) Other lot! Other lot!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Jonah, stop! Marlo attempts to respond calmly, but she’s unraveling.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (to Sarah) You know how he is with his routine. He doesn’t like when we do things differently.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Nobody cares about what I like! Jonah is WAILING at this point.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Jonah, the other lot is full. There’s nowhere to park. (desperate) Jesus Christ. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A different, crowded parking lot; Jonah got his way. One pulls out of a spot; Marlo’s car is braked patiently, wai for said spot. Marlo’s car pulls into the spot. INT. MARLO’S CAR - SAME

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (to Jonah) All right, you happy? Jonah nods, tear-stained.  INT. SCHOOL (PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE) - DAY Marlo enters the PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE, flustered. MRS. BELL a.k.a. LAURIE, waits at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Hi Laurie. I’m sorry I’m late. (lying) Regent was backed-up for blocks.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Hi Marlo. Are you on maternity leave yet? You look like you're about to pop.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah. Friday was my last day. Marlo stands awkwardly in front of the desk, forcing a bi fake expectant smile. This is her “school persona.”

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Such a blessing.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I’ll try not to take up too much of your time here, so I’ll just get right to it: Ms. Marvish tells me that Jonah is still having a tough time in class. We’re concerned about his social and emotional development.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Kindergarten’s a tough transition.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: It’s April.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (sheepish) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: And there’s about to be a big disruption in Jonah’s life, too.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What? Laurie nods at Marlo’s huge belly: duh. MARLO (CONT’D) Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah’s sweetheart. We love him. But as you know, he’s an “out-of- the-box” kid. He’s quirky. Marlo nods, subtly lip-syncing the word “quirky” as Lauri says it. It’s a euphemism that comes up a lot regarding Jonah. LAURIE (CONT’D) There are twenty-four other children in the class, and it’s not fair to them when Jonah needs so much of the teacher’s time. Marlo’s response is eager, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: We’re working on the meltdowns at home. And we’re doing these exercises and all this stuff. I just made this chart--

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) We think Jonah could benefit from a one-to-one aide. A teacher just for him, who shadows him during the day and gives him the extra support he requires.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Is the aide someone on staff here?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: No, we don’t provide aides.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Oh, so I have to go out and get AIDS all by myself. She chuckles dryly at her own joke. Laurie doesn’t catch

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Yes, you’d need to hire this person.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I’m paying to get AIDS!

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (confused) One aide. He just needs one.  Marlo nods seriously, giving up on the AIDS joke.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Right. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: We don’t usually make these kinds of accommodations for students at Saint V.’s, but you guys are a great family, so...

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Thank you, Laurie. I really, really appreciate it. I want to make this work.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: No problem. Have a great day now. Marlo musters a smile and rises to exit, shattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the kids dropped off and a temporary reprieve from w Marlo enters the local COFFEE PLACE on the town’s main dr She heads to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I’ll have a decaf skim latte please. An OLDER FEMALE CUSTOMER behind Marlo pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: NOSY CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: You know there’s trace amounts of caffeine even in decaf, right?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Huh? The women gestures to Marlo’s PREGNANT BELLY. MARLO (CONT’D) Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NOSY CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Just so you know.

dialogues.speaker: BARISTA
dialogues.text: You still want it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NOSY CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Just don’t overdo it! (then, know-it-all) My daughter has three, so I read up on all this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: This is my third as well.

dialogues.speaker: NOSY CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Are your children short-statured?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NOSY CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: From the caffeine. The BARISTA is tapping out a total on the register.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yes. My kids are miniature. And my son actually came out with the Starbucks logo burned into his ass like a cattle brand.

dialogues.speaker: BARISTA
dialogues.text: Would you like any sweetener with that?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah. Give me the one that causes cancer in rats. The barista shrugs and tosses four PINK PACKETS at Marlo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo, seated at a table, takes a voracious bite of a gia MUFFIN. She drinks her latte. Suddenly--

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Marlo? VIOLET, a woman about Marlo’s age approaches the table. S unconventionally attractive with an artistic style. She carries a to-go box of coffee and her mouth is agape.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You said it. They stare at each other for a moment, stunned. MARLO (CONT’D) What are you doing in Rye?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m here for a memorial. My friend’s dad passed away.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: It’s fine. He was a dick. Marlo’s sudden laugh is a GOOFY BARK. She covers her mout

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Jesus. What was that?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That’s the standard “Marlo laugh.” Somewhere between a bike horn and a goose orgy. I miss it. Violet pulls up a chair and sits down. There’s ELECTRIC NOSTALGIA in the air-- and also considerable awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So do you live here? Fill me in on everything. I mean, you randomly dropped off Facebook like five years ago, never to be heard from again, so. This is lightly delivered, but there’s hurt beneath...

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I hate social media.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: We all do. That’s the point. It’s a mandatory rage-fuck.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Ha. Well, I live here in town. Still married to Drew. Two kids. Nothing’s changed.  11.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Mm, I don’t know how to tell you this, but you’ve really blown up. Marlo laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, congrats. Anyway, I have to get this coffee back to the house before it gets as cold and black as my womb. Do you still have my number?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: The same one? 718?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Same number as always, and same address too.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (surprised) What? You’re still at the loft?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Mm-hm. Still in Bushwick. Building went co-op years ago, so I bought the place. I’m surrounded by Millennials crying on the phone to Mommy. Call me sometime, okay? If you feel like it. Marlo nods as Violet exits. Once Violet is gone. Marlo si and stares at her muffin for a moment. Her cheeks are red When she reaches for her latte, the cup RATTLES briefly against the saucer. INT. MARLO’S CAR - NIGHT Drew, Marlo, Sarah and Jonah are in the car headed to Mar brother’s house. Marlo, drained by the day’s events, clut a bottle of cheap wine in the passenger’s seat.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (to the kids) Are you guys excited to see your cousins?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Is the dog going to be out?  12.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Jonah, the dog weighs like two pounds. He can’t hurt you. Jonah moans, worried as usual.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What is that dog’s name again?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: “Prosecco.”

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I want to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Mommy’s joking. Like a clown. Marlo “honks” her own nose in response.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Beep-beep. EXT. CRAIG AND ELYSE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Marlo’s older brother CRAIG lives in a newly constructed “French”-style mansion with a motor court and fountain. I incredibly grand compared to Marlo and Craig’s little rambler. Jonah spots Craig’s new car.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Is that Uncle Craig's electric car?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s called a Tesla.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Can we get one?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t want one. They catch on fire all the time. Drew snorts at Marlo’s lie.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Really?  13.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah, like five kids died in one last week. It burst into flames while they were on their way to see the Easter Bunny at Monmouth Mall.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You're lying!

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Don’t get too close to it. INT./EXT CRAIG AND ELYSE’S HOUSE (ENTRY) - NIGHT Drew knocks on the oversized front door. It swings open. Reveal ELYSE, Marlo’s smiling sister-in-law, who is whipp thin and gorgeous in a cashmere sweater and jeans. An expensive-looking DOG barks behind her.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Heyyyyyyy! Everyone greets each other. The kids hug Aunt Elyse, who upbeat and affectionate. Elyse’s three kids, DASH, EMMY a GRETA appear, excited to see their cousins.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to kids) What’s up buddy? Sarah, I’m going to steal those boots right off your feet. So cute.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Hey, Elyse. An energetic young woman, SHASTA, appears in the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA
dialogues.text: (to Marlo’s kids) Hi guys. I made an obstacle course in the playroom if you want to come check it out! Emmy, 10, makes an introduction.

dialogues.speaker: EMMY
dialogues.text: This is Shasta, our nanny.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hi. Four year-old Greta pipes up.  14.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: We have karaoke!

dialogues.speaker: EMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah, we got a karaoke machine.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Cool! Greta grabs Jonah’s hand. All five kids joyously run off toward the playroom with Shasta.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Shasta’s so awesome. She has a masters degree in Early Childhood Education. I feel like she should be telling me what to do. (then) Marlo, you are glowing. Marlo looks like death warmed over.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Really? I feel like an abandoned trash barge.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: In the eighties there was this giant boat full of garbage that just drifted up and down the East Coast for weeks. They couldn’t figure out where to dump it. Eventually, they docked the boat in Brooklyn and burned all the trash. Elyse hesitates, then laughs cheerfully.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: The ninth month is tough. I remember I could barely make it to the gym. Come on! INT. CRAIG AND ELYSE’S HOUSE (VARIOUS/KITCHEN) - NIGHT Elyse leads Drew and Marlo into the gigantic kitchen, whe Marlo’s brother CRAIG is opening a bottle of wine. Craig charming, gregarious guy. He’s wearing an expensive suit, tie loosened.  15.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. The Moreaus have arrived. This is gonna be a good night. Drew, how are you, buddy? He and Drew do the one-armed guy hug. Drew sheds his jack tossing it on a stool.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marlo. Marlo tries to accept his hug, but her belly gets in the

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I have my own hug-buffer now.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Just what you've always wanted.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: That’s actually true.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: When is your due date again?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Monday.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Jesus. Don’t have it here.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: (to Craig) She could have it in the ofuro! (then) We just got this Japanese soaking tub. It was a gift from Craig’s boss. She shrugs like, isn’t that weird?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: My boss once bought me a cup of soup. I paid him back. Elyse assesses Marlo’s belly.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: You know, I feel like it’s definitely a boy.  16.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Marlo didn’t want to know this time, but I kind of wish we had decided to find out.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Well, you’re going to find out any day now. Craig and Elyse smile, awaiting a response from Marlo. Is this exciting? She fakes a smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yep. INT. CRAIG AND ELYSE’S HOUSE (DINING ROOM) - NIGHT Marlo, Craig and Drew walk into the dining room, holding drinks and chatting. The table is gorgeous and rustic, wi flickering candles and artfully mismatched plates and goblets. It’s perfect without trying too hard. Marlo noti that there are only four place settings at the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Where are the kids going to sit?

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Oh, they’re with Shasta. They have their own little kid-friendly spread. Mac and cheese, Kobe sliders, something green...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Lucky little bastards.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Wow, we can actually have a conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: I know, right? She fiddles with her phone and speaks into it.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Siri. Play Hamilton. Music fills the room via Wi-Fi. Elyse looks pleased with herself for liking hip hop.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: So, three.  17. Marlo is confused for a beat, then realizes Craig is referring to her pregnancy. He nods at her belly.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah. It’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: You’re going to love it. We love having three. And the third kid is always the easiest. (to Craig) Right? Greta’s so chill.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Chill would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you guys really have your hands full with Jonah. (quickly) I don’t mean that in a bad way. He’s so great.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: No, he’s tough. He’s quirky. The school actually wants us to get him a aide because the teacher can’t handle him anymore. Marlo glances at Drew, flustered that he would disclose t Drew eats matter-of-factly.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, that’s awesome. (spinning it) That they’re, you know, recognizing his needs.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, they’re all over it. INT. CRAIG AND ELYSE’S HOUSE (KITCHEN) - NIGHT Elyse enters the kitchen, protesting as Drew and Marlo attempt to carry in the dirty serving dishes.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Guys, do not help. I got it. She hands a platter to a waiting HOUSEKEEPER.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Let me at least put this away.  18.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: No. You're not allowed. Besides, I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I saw the Tesla.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, no. Come here. He puts a brotherly hand on Marlo’s shoulder and steers h away from the sink. INT. CRAIG AND ELYSE’S HOUSE (TIKI BAR) - NIGHT Craig has a TAHITIAN-STYLE home bar that looks like somet at a resort. Marlo looks around at the decor

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You like it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It’s like I’ve been transported to another room of your house.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: It was inspired by the most beautiful place I’ve ever been.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Tahiti?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Epcot. Marlo climbs awkwardly onto a stool. Craig goes behind th bar and pours himself a scotch and Marlo a pineapple juic

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, I have a special baby gift for you this time around.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Is it money?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Ha ha. It’s more like an experience.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Okay...  19.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Have you ever heard of a night nanny? Before Marlo gets a chance to reply...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quickly) Everyone does it. I mean, everyone we know. It’s like a regular nanny, but she only comes to your house at night. She stays over for a few weeks-- or months-- and takes care of the new baby so Mom and Dad can get some sleep! His tone is cheerful, careful. What is he getting at?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: How does that work? Does this lady breast-feed? Jesus, there’s nothing you people won’t outsource.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: No! She doesn’t breast-feed. This isn’t feudal China. She wakes you up to do... (gesturing, awkward) That. But then you can go right back to bed when you’re done.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Why have a baby if you’re not willing to put in the time? Sleep deprivation is part of the deal. Besides, I don’t want some stranger in my house bonding with my newborn at night. That’s like a Lifetime movie where the nanny tries to kill the mom and the mom wins but still walks with a cane for the rest of her life.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: We had a night nanny.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You did? I don’t remember that.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: That’s because she was only here at night! They come in and out like a ninja. I barely had any interaction with the woman. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Elyse said she was great.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Craig, you didn’t hire one of these people for me, did you? Craig’s tone becomes more serious.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Marlo. You’ve got a lot going on. I know this kid wasn’t planned, okay? I know, I know, it’s a miracle and the best thing ever and blah blah blah... Craig lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...But I don’t want what happened last time to happen again.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Craig, don't...

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I love you. I don’t want to ever see you that way (again)

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (over) It won’t happen. Just stop.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Drew needs to focus on his career. He’s finally getting somewhere and you can’t let this baby derail him. And you need to be there for Jonah and Sarah. Get them to school in the morning. Be “happy Mommy.” Awake. Present. Especially for Jonah. The mention of Jonah gives Marlo guilty pause.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know you think this is some bougie thing that rich assholes do. And maybe it is. But remember, I wasn’t always a rich asshole. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I grew up in the same shitty house as you, with the same shitty parents and that shit-brown Buick on the lawn. And I’m telling you-- for the sake of your kids-- get over yourself and call her. He reaches into his pocket and hands her a folded-up piec paper.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is the number. Make whatever arrangements you need, for however long you want. She’1ll bill me; we already worked it out. This isn’t the person we used-- she was booked until August-- but this one comes highly recommended. Think about it. Marlo tucks the folded paper into her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: How much money does this cost?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: An assload. (then, serious) Think about it. INT. MARLO’S CAR - NIGHT Marlo is driving. A tipsy Drew is in the passenger seat. Marlo rants about Craig’s proposal.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (mid-rant) .»-I mean, I understand having a cleaning lady or a babysitter or whatever if you can afford it. But the “night nanny” thing just sounds crazy. Like, what is this, Downton Abbey?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: It sounds pretty ideal to me. Like, not having to wake up five times a night or whatever?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You don’t wake up anyway. Her observation is matter-of-fact, not hostile.  22.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I don’t have boobs, Marlo.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s true.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: It’s not like I can do anything. They’ve arrives a stoplight. Marlo looks out the window a group of YOUNG PEOPLE congregating on a sidewalk. They're talking and laughing, animated.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I’m fine with doing it myself anyway. You need to be rested for work. This is a big year for you. As she recites this, she’s fixated on the young crowd.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: You’re sure you’re going to be okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Of course. He notices that she’s spaced-out.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Honey?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: It’s green. The light has changed. Marlo accelerates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are off. Drew sleeps. Marlo is lying in bed, wrestling with a huge snakelike body pillow. She can’t ge comfortable. She settles for a moment. We hear a distinct POP. Marlo’s eyes open. Marlo gets up and walks to the bathroom. From her P.O.V., see WATER dribbling onto the floor with every step. It’s the dramatic scene we see in movies, just a tiny dribble. it’s unmistakable.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A disoriented Drew drives to the hospital. Marlo rides quietly in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew holds Marlo’s hand while an ANESTHESIOLOGIST who loo sixteen years old injects an EPIDURAL into her spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo watches E! News on TV in her hospital bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo lies on her side checking her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo is pushing out her baby. A DOCTOR and a couple of NURSES are there. Drew stands by taking video with his ph A not-particularly-meaningful SONG plays on someone’s iPo The doctor is laid-back, almost distracted.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Okay, can you feel my hand inside you? Push against my hand. One, two, three. Marlo closes her eyes and pushes silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo is sitting up in the hospital bed, still wearing a hospital gown and tethered to an I.V. Craig and Elyse are the room. Elyse holds the BABY, making little cooing nois

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Marlo, she is your mini. Look at those lips.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I wish we could stay, but Emmy’s in the middle school musical tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What show is it?  24.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: (proud) Rent.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I don’t get it. It’s like, just pay your fucking rent. Problem solved. Elyse is about to pass back the sleeping baby back to Mar

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You can just put her in the bassinet.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. Surprised, she places the baby in the hospital bassinet. Craig leans in and pats Marlo’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You take it easy, okay? And tell Dad congrats when he wakes up. Reveal Drew SOUND ASLEEP on a cot. Craig and Elyse quietl exit the room. Marlo swings her numb legs out of bed and tries to get up It’s tough. She looks over at Drew. He is sound asleep on cot. Marlo manages to get up and walks gingerly toward the bathroom, dragging her I.V. behind her. She stumbles into door frame. Through the open back of her hospital gown, w see she’s wearing an ADULT DIAPER. Marlo reaches for the nurse call button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig and Elyse walk to the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: So did you talk to her about the night nanny?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Yeah. She said she could never let a stranger take care of her baby.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Oh, so she’s judging our choices. Nice.  25. Craig pushes the elevator button.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I just want my sister back. The last few years... She used to be happy, you know?

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Wasn’t she also like, totally irresponsible?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: She got a little wild sometimes, sure. But overall, she was just fun to be around. Then she had the kids. Once Sarah came along, it was like somebody snuffed the match. And when Jonah was born... They shudder at the unspoken.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that wasn't pretty. (then) Maybe you should call Drew and see if he can convince her.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Drew hates me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo sits on the toilet in the cramped bathroom while a motherly RUSSIAN NURSE encourages her.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN NURSE
dialogues.text: You have to show me you can do a pee-pee.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It’s just not coming out.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN NURSE
dialogues.text: If you don’t pee soon, we have to put the catheter back in. Marlo strains desperately, hoping to avoid this outcome. hear a trickling/pouring sound.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: There. She struggles to stand up. The nurse glances into the bow  26.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN NURSE
dialogues.text: That’s not enough.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Why is this so important?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN NURSE
dialogues.text: Don’t get angry.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I peed. Why don’t you believe me? It’s in there, I swear. Run a test or something. (angry) How much do you fucking need? Do I have to spray it all over the room? You want a golden shower?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN NURSE
dialogues.text: You need to rest, mommy. We hear the baby CRY OUT. RUSSIAN NURSE (CONT’D) I can take her to the nursery.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: No. She needs me. I’m the only one who can do it. She staggers out of the bathroom toward her baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo nurses the baby alone. The T.V. flickers in the dar living room. It could be 2:00 am, could be 4:00. Time doe exist anymore. The living room is temporarily “baby central.” There’s a portable BASSINET (known in parental circles as a Pack n’ Play), a pile of diapers and a makeshift CHANGING STATION a chair. Marlo closes her eyes. She opens them. Her arms are empty THE BABY IS GONE. She leaps to her feet, panics. Scans the floor. Runs to t kitchen. She hears a coo coming from the kitchen sink. A baby's arm, waving. What is the baby doing in the sink? Marlo opens her eyes. The baby is in her arms, still nurs It was a dream, a weird one.  27. Through a series of dissolves, we see a MONTAGE of endles grinding, exhausting DAYS and NIGHTS of baby care. We nev leave the living room. Marlo sleeps on the couch with a blanket and pillow-- when she gets to sleep. Marlo is suddenly DRIVING HER CAR. Jonah is inexplicably illegally) sitting in the front seat. Marlo glances in th rear view and sees the BABY lying in the back seat. She S on the brakes, gasping. She looks over at Jonah, who has turned into a DISAPPROVING OLDER WOMAN. (Her mother?) Marlo suddenly wakes up, in her makeshift bed on the couc The baby is in her arms. What time is it? Hard to say. Dr in a suit and tie, enters to kiss the baby goodbye and he to work. He looks so polished. Marlo, so feral. Marlo paces, nurses, feeds. Her clothes change, but they’ all the same variation on T-shirt and sweat pants. Marlo is lying on the floor of a FOREST, gazing up at the sky. It's peaceful for a moment. Someone POKES her with a stick in the shoulder. Poke. Poke. Poke. Poke. Marlo wakes up. She’s fallen asleep sitting up. Jonah is repeatedly poking her in the shoulder with a TOY LIGHT SA Later: Jonah and Sarah are watching cartoons. Sarah tries snuggle up to her mom, who barely responds. Marlo stares blankly at Barbie’s Mermaid Adventure. Her e brim with TEARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo walks down the hallway with Jonah like a zombie. Sh carries the baby’s INFANT CAR SEAT by its handle; it has muslin blanket draped over it so we can’t see the baby. T arrive at his KINDERGARTEN CLASSROOM.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (distracted) Love you. Jonah jumps up and down and licks Marlo’s sleeve, clingin her. She manages to detach him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. Jonah dashes into his classroom. Marlo continues down the hallway.  28. INT. SAINT VITUS SCHOOL (PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE) - DAY Laurie is seated at her desk, drinking coffee and pushing paper. Marlo enters, escorted by a MALE SECRETARY.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Hi. Thank you so much for coming in today. I know mornings aren’t easy. Especially for you right now.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Why? Laurie gestures to the car seat warmly. MARLO (CONT’D) Oh, yeah. Marlo sits down in front of the principal’s desk and plac the car seat on the floor. Laurie obviously finds it a li odd that Marlo doesn’t want to show off or talk about the baby, but says nothing. She comes around to Marlo’s side the desk and sits in the other chair there.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: So, we’re coming up on the end of the kindergarten year, and I just wanted to talk to you about Mister Jonah! Her quasi-affectionate use of “Mister” doesn’t mask the tension.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: We're getting him the aide. The one- one aide. We just have to figure out how we’re going to pay... Her voice trails off. She’s sick of talking about it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Right. I know. (then) Back when you guys applied, we did express some concerns about whether or not Saint Vitus was the right fit for Jonah. But we love your family, and we have such a great relationship with your brother and his wife...  29.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I know Jonah is only here because of them.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: That’s not--

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: No, I know. They’re big donors and they called in a favor. Now Laurie is uncomfortable. She takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: We think Jonah might be better served by a different school.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You’re expelling him?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: No, Marlo... Expulsion is a punishment. We would call this a dismissal.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: There are places better suited to kids like Jonah.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What does that mean, “kids like Jonah?”

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Well, you know, Jonah is quirky.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (interrupting) What is this “quirky” thing everyone keeps saying? (officious voice) “Parenting Your Quirky Child.” It’s so stupid. What does it mean? It’s like, do I have a kid or a fucking ukelele? Why can’t you say what you mean, which is that you think Jonah is retarded? And he’s ruining it for all the other kids in the class who are reading like, The Iliad or whatever? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry about my retarded son. Oh, I’m sorry, quirky. Because he’s a pocket watch. Fuck. This. She stands up and grabs the baby carrier. Mrs. Bell is alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Jonah is bright. He’s great. It’s just not the right fit.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Just say what you mean. You hate my kid. You hate us. The secretary appears, having overheard the skirmish.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: (shaken) Dallas, please walk her out.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Don’t touch me, Dallas.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t--

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: You need to calm down. I’m not letting you leave like this.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Oh, I leave like this every day; you just don’t know it. This is the real me, when I’m not licking your asshole. Surprise! Marlo turns and accidentally SLAMS the unwieldy car seat against the frame of the door. We hear the baby SQUEAL. Laurie and the secretary gasp. MARLO (CONT’D) She's FINE. She manages to exit, leaving the stunned pair in her wake

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo steps up into her van and manages to snap the baby’ car seat into its base. She climbs into the driver's seat and stares into space, breathing heavily. The baby begins CRYING in the back seat.  31. Marlo climbs into the backseat. She finds a pacifier in t baby’s seat and sucks on it to “clean” it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Here. The baby rejects the pacifier. MARLO (CONT’D) (desperate) Take it. Just take it. The baby finally starts sucking. Marlo collapses in the unoccupied captain’s chair next to the baby. Now it’s Mar turn to burst into TEARS. Her shoulders heave. Marlo makes a decision. She crawls down onto the floor of van and searches for something. There’s a lot of garbage family detritus. Then, under the driver’s seat, she finds what she’s looking for. She unfolds the PIECE OF PAPER with shaking hands. MARLO (CONT’D) (reading) Tully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are watching TV. Marlo takes a FROZEN PIZZA out the oven and slaps it down on a cutting board. She drains some broccoli from a pot on the stove and divides it on t two plates. Just going through the motions.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Daddy! We hear the FRONT DOOR open. The kids get up and run to t door to greet Drew, thrilled to finally get some attentio A suit-clad Drew walks in, flanked by Sarah and Jonah.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Frozen pizza, all right. (noticing the TV) I thought we weren’t doing screen time during the week? Marlo just looks at him with hollow eyes. Drew puts his p up helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Fine with me. It’s your rule.  He walks to the kitchen table and sits. the plates and sits down. The kids take their places. He laughs,

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: So, uh, I decided to call that night nanny.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: (surprised) You did?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I just-- you know, Craig’s paying for it, so I’m sure he’1ll lord that over us. barely masking his annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry. I wouldn’t want you to sustain a bruise to your ego. That’s cool. I‘1l just cancel. I’1l just cancel and make another pot of coffee. We’re good.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: No, no! I’m sorry. I didn’t mean-- (concerned) Are you okay? Marlo shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Guys, is Mommy okay?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: She’s coming tonight at 10:30. 32. Marlo comes over with Jonah knocks over a GLASS OF MILK. It spills directly ont Marlo’s shirt and lap, but she doesn’t flinch.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Jesus! Careful, Jonah. Marlo peels off her shirt wordlessly. She sits in a NURSI BRA. Her body is a deflated, stretch-marked mess. Drew lo away. Sarah’s eyes widen with comic amusement.  33.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Mom, what’s wrong with your body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo sits in the dimly lit living room, holding the baby She watches HBO’s Cathouse with the closed-captioning on. Onscreen, a naked PROSTITUTE negotiates with a john. The is a wreck. We hear a soft KNOCK. Marlo gets up and hurries quietly t the door with the baby on her shoulder. She opens the doo revealing TULLY, the night nurse, standing there bathed i porch light.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Hello. I’m Tully. Tully is in her early twenties. Her hair is long; she wea T-shirt and jeans and has a BACKPACK slung over her shoul There’s punky black EYELINER applied in cat-like swipes a her eyes. She looks like a friendly grad student with sla tendencies. Marlo is taken aback; this is not what she expected.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You must be Marlo.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: May I come in? Marlo steps aside wordlessly. Tully enters.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (indicating the baby) Who’s this?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You mean the baby?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Yes. What’s her name? For some reason, the question startles Marlo. It’s as tho she’d forgotten the baby was human.  34.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Her name is Mia. Tully is examining the baby, who is snuggled against Marl shoulder. We see the baby’s FACE for the first time. Her are open. She is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Mia. Marlo rambles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It was my mother’s name. I always said I would use it. But now it’s really popular, I guess. She shrugs as if apologizing for her choice.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Who cares?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Who cares if it’s popular? It’s a beautiful name. She touches Mia’s cheek. Mia coos. Marlo is mesmerized by Tully’s calm, direct manner.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It is. (then) How old are you? Tully smiles. Marlo checks herself. MARLO (CONT’D) I’m sorry; I just wasn’t expecting--

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Don’t apologize. I get that a lot. I’m older than I look. There’s an awkward beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: So, how does this work?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: How do you want it to work?  35.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I have no idea. Tully strides confidently into the house proper. Marlo follows behind her, as if being led into her own home.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I’m here to take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I thought you were here to take care of the baby.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Well, you kind of are the baby. Marlo chuckles, confused.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even though this one’s been earthside for three weeks, her DNA is still inside of you. In fact, her cells will hang around in your bloodstream for years. As she speaks, Tully reaches for Mia. Marlo hands Mia ove without hesitation, surprising herself.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And though Mia here will be her own person someday, right now she’s still very much a part of you. She knows your voice, your smell, your heartbeat. And you know her better than anyone. You built her from the toes up. Marlo just stares at Tully. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I feel like I don’t know her at all yet.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: It’1ll come. She smiles reassuringly-- and we believe her.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Okay. They’re standing in the KITCHEN now.  36.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I'll be here as long as you need me. You look like you could use some rest. I’1ll settle in with Mia down here. You go upstairs and sleep. Marlo seems shocked by this suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Don’t I need to show you what to do?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Are there diapers down here?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Does she have a place to sleep?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: There’s a bassinet in the den.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Then we're good. I’1ll come wake you up when she’s ready to nurse. Marlo nods, confused. Sleep-deprived. But game.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Okay. See you soon. Tully smiles kindly.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: “And so to bed.”

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Samuel Pepys. He kept a diary during the English Restoration.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Right. Samuel Pepys. She turns, shaking her head, and heads toward the stairs. Tully looks down at Mia, now awake, and smiles beatifical  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo enters the bedroom. Drew is in bed. The lights are He wears a GAMING HEADSET as he plays SKYRIM on his Xbox. pulls off his headset when he sees Marlo, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: The night nanny is here.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? What’s she like?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (whispering) Weird.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: She’s weird.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Are you going to just leave her down there with Mia? Marlo ponders this briefly.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Okay. Marlo climbs into bed. She closes her eyes, overwhelmed b the sudden possibility of sleep. A moment later, she rises from the bed, anxious. She walk toward the bedroom door. Opens it, revealing not the hall but... A BEACH...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo is standing at the edge of the ocean in a bikini. H body is beautiful, like it used to be. She runs her hands over her flat belly.  38. She looks down and sees MIA lying on the sand, alert and kicking.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (to Mia) Don't go anywhere. She walks into the ocean. It's beautiful. The sun shines the water. Marlo ducks under. Suddenly, she's in a deep swimming poo She swims down, down. We hear the song “Blue” again, but a muffled, underwater version. The floor of the pool is strewn with TOYS and random detritus, like an empty FROZEN PIZZA BOX. There's a MERMAID down there. Her hair undulates like kel The mermaid turns around smiles at her. It's TULLY. The T mermaid swims up to Marlo.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Don't come up too fast.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo opens her eyes. Tully is standing over her, holding and speaking softly.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: There you go. Nice and easy. Hi, Marlo. She’s ready for you. Marlo is disoriented. Hair is plastered to her cheek with drool. Drew is sound asleep next to her. Mia fusses a bit

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll help. She leans down and un-clicks the strap of Marlo’s nursing tank top. It’s a weirdly intimate gesture, but appreciate Marlo takes the baby wordlessly and feeds her. Tully sits cross-legged on the floor of the dark bedroom. She stares serenely at Marlo, not breaking eye-contact.  39. INT. MARLO AND DREW’S HOUSE (BEDROOM) - MORNING We hear the sound of a BABY STIRRING. Marlo wakes up. It’s Saturday morning. Birds chirp. Drew still sleeping. An audio-only BABY MONITOR is plugged in to the bed; Mia’s little noises are being transmitted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo wanders downstairs. She gasps. The house is IMMACUL Almost unrecognizable. The kitchen GLEAMS. There are YELL DAFFODILS picked from the back yard, arranged in a vase. Marlo walks over to the bassinet. Mia is swaddled neatly she stirs. Jonah emerges behind Marlo, bleary-eyed in his pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Is it a school day or a family day?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It’s Sunday. It’s a family day. Jonah looks around the room, confused.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Why is it clean?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo and Drew walk through a LOCAL PARK while Sarah runs ahead in her SOCCER UNIFORM and Jonah rides a scooter.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: (incredulous) So she was in our bedroom last night?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yes. She brought Mia to me to nurse and she just sort of sat in the shadows and waited for me to finish.  40.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: And then she went downstairs and chiseled the filth off our floors. Doesn’t she sleep?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Maybe she’s nocturnal. Like an owl.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Or Sarah's hamster. Remember that thing? The wheel going all night long... Sarah runs over, interrupting the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Mom, I need water. Drew rolls his eyes as Marlo dutifully produces a Thermos

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: The game didn’t even start yet!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: So? I’m thirsty. Marlo offers Sarah water. Marlo resumes the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: The nanny just seems so serene. Like she really enjoys taking care of people.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with her?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Right? INT. Marlo AND DREW'S HOUSE (LIVING ROOM/ENTRY) - NIGHT Marlo is watching Cathouse again and holding Mia. We hear Tully’s soft, signature knock. Marlo hurries to the door. A smiling Tully, casually attired in a Jayhawks T-shirt, stands on the threshold with her backpack.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Good evening!  41.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Hi. Hey, I just wanted to thank you for cleaning the house. You really, really didn’t have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I enjoyed it. I have an energy surplus. Like Saudi Arabia.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (WTF )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, all right. As they enter the den, Marlo realizes that she has forgot to turn off the television. A client and a topless hooker interacting on Cathouse. MARLO (CONT’D) Oh, God! I’m sorry. Embarrassed, she reaches for the remote. Tully stops her.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: No. What is this?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It’s an old reality show. It’s called Cathouse.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: What’s it about? People are FUCKING on the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Um, the goings-on at a legal whorehouse in Nevada. Just, you know, day-to-day operations. Tully looks at the smiling BLONDE onscreen.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Who's she?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: That’s Air Force Amy.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Is she a pilot?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: No... I’m going to turn this off.  42.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: There’s really no need. You're enjoying it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I’m not enjoying it. It just happened to be on... She realizes she’s hit pause on the RECORDING she’s made.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --.my DVR.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Marlo, I want to make it abundantly clear that you can’t be self- conscious around me. This won’t work if you are.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I’m just not used to being served, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Relax and accept my service. Pretend I’m Air Force Amy. The conversation has reached peak weirdness.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, I’m just going to go upstairs and watch a movie with Drew. Tully has scooped up a cooing Mia.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Have fun. You know, I can put on headphones if you guys want to be intimate.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: We’re not loud. I mean, that’s fine. Tully holds Mia up in Marlo’s face.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Kiss good night? Tomorrow she’1ll be different.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: In what way?  43.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: She’1l grow a little overnight. And so will we. With her eyes fixed warily on Tully, Marlo leans in kisse Mia’s cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew is watching Orphan Black on Netflix. Marlo pulls out iPad from under the bed and immediately starts tapping aw Marlo and Drew don’t acknowledge each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo wakes up. She massages her breasts; they’re uncomfortably full. The clock on the night stand reads 2: am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo walks into the living room. Tully is perched on a chair, holding Mia as she sleeps. She smiles at Marlo.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Hi there.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Hey. I think I need to nurse her. I feel like I’m going to explode. She subtly indicates her engorged boobs.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Sure. Let’s do a dream feed. Marlo settles onto the couch while Tully hands her the ba She lifts her shirt as a sleeping Mia latches on. Marlo WINCES in pain-- it’s intense.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s got a strong latch.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yes, she’s a barnacle.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: If she’s a barnacle, then are you a boat, or are you a whale?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Well, boats get hurt by barnacles. But whales don’t. When a barnacle latches onto a whales, it’s harmless. It’s just a little obligate parasite doing its thing. Tully smiles. Marlo looks down at Mia’s little face, choo not to continue with this odd conversation.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does she look like your other kids?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Huh? Yeah, she looks a lot like Sarah. My daughter.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: What’s Sarah like??

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Well, Sarah’s eight. She’s getting to this age where she can be really hard on herself. And that makes me nervous, because it doesn’t get better for girls, you know?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: No, it doesn’t. There’s a KNOWING SADNESS in Tully’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: And my son Jonah... well, he’s pretty great. But he’s exhausting. He all these weird behaviors and anxieties. We have to brush him. Like, I have to brush his body at night. Like a horse.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Well, a therapist told us that it’s supposed to reduce his sensitivities to everyday things. (sheepish) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can’t afford to take him to a therapist anymore, so I just watched YouTube and learned the exercises. It’s called the “Wilbarger Brush Protocol.”

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: “Protocol.”

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Right? It sounds like a Tom Cruise movie, except shitty and kind of sad. Anyway, it’s my fault he has all these issues.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Why is it your fault? Marlo hesitates. She’s not ready to share this informatio with a near-stranger.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You don’t have to talk about it. (beat) You seem like an amazing mom.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah, you'd be “amazed” by how much I suck.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Why would you say that?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Well, I know moms who are really amazing. They organize the class parties and “Casino Night,” and they make little cupcakes with googly-eyes. All that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You’re laying bedrock; they’re planting flowers.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: But I want to be the cupcake mom. I used to love to bake. But now I’m so exhausted. Even getting dressed feels like work. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every morning I open my closet and think “Didn’t I just do this?” And that continues for the rest of the day. “Didn’t I just do this?” My life is like stuck on repeat mode.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: That’s the downside of living on a planet with a short solar day. Although Jupiter’s even shorter.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You’re like a book of fun facts for unpopular fourth graders.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Thank you. (then) What do you do for work, Marlo?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I’m the office manager at a company that makes protein bars. I have a useless degree in Philosophy, so now I write emails letting people know they can’t wear Crocs on “casual Friday.” Or sometimes, you know, I’1l make a sign for the ladies room that says “Please stop flushing tampons. Your bitch- missiles are clogging the pipes. XO, Marlo.” It’s deeply fulfilling.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: What do you wish you did?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: That’s the problem. I don’t know. If I had some big dream that never came true, I could at least be pissed off at the world. Instead, I’m just pissed off at myself.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You’re empty.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: No, I mean you’re empty on that side. She’s done. I’1ll take her.  47. .»..Or not. Tully gently takes Mia from Marlo. Marlo seem reluctant to go back to bed. She heads toward the stairs, then turns.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Thanks for the, uh, interview. It was cathartic. We sense that it really was.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Come back to the couch any time. She flashes Marlo the peace sign.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marlo?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (turning) Hm?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I’m here to help you with everything. Not just Mia. I can’t fix the parts without treating the whole.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: No one’s treated my “hole” ina long time.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Now, if that were true, we wouldn't have Mia. Sleep tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6:00 AM. Marlo comes downstairs, bleary eyed. She carries Jonah; he’s almost too big to be held, but he still fits.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Are we going to have a good day today? Jonah MEOWS in response. MARLO (CONT’D) Oh, you're a kitty? Marlo sees something on the counter: it’s a tray of WHIMS CUPCAKES with GOOGLY EYES. They’re beautifully decorated, even Pinterest-worthy.  48.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the f...? Jonah scampers over to the cupcakes, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Mom! Did you make these? They’re funny!

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: They sure are. She picks one up, admiring the craftsmanship. MARLO (CONT’D) You want to take these to school?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Yes! For my friends! He hugs Marlo’s leg happily. Heartbreaking. INT. SAINT VITUS SCHOOL (JONAH’S CLASSROOM) - DAY Marlo, looking unusually bright and put-together, walks J into his classroom. She “wears” Mia in a comfy-looking WR a far cry from the car seat she carried her in during the last time we saw her at school. Class hasn’t started yet, but around ten KIDS scamper aro socializing. Marlo peels the foil back from the tray, flashing the cupcakes at Jonah’s teacher, MRS. MARVISH.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Okay if we brought in a treat? They’re nut-free. The handful of KIDS in the classroom roar with approval. even runs up and hugs Jonah, who beams. But Mrs. Marvish seems oddly skittish.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARVISH
dialogues.text: What’s the occasion?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: No occasion. I just love to bake. Marlo reads Mrs. Marvish’s nervous expression. MARLO (CONT’D) Oh... You heard about... it’s fine. I get it. No hard feelings about Jonah or anything. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARLO (CONT’D) In fact, I kind of made these as a peace offering. You know, I’m going to bring one to Mrs. Bell, since she’s the one I... Marlo plucks a cupcake from the tray as she stammers this nervous apology.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MARVISH
dialogues.text: Okay. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Have a good day! INT. SAINT VITUS SCHOOL (PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE) - DAY Laurie’s office door is open; she’s discussing something her secretary, Dallas. Marlo knocks on the door frame. Wh Laurie and Dallas see Marlo, they both BLANCH from fear. Dallas practically jumps a foot.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Hi. (off their expressions) Don’t freak out. I’m here to apologize for the other day. I brought an olive branch of sorts. Actually it’s a strawberry cupcake with cream cheese frosting but who wants a actual olive branch, right? No thanks! Bleh. She tentatively places the cupcake on Laurie’s desk. MARLO (CONT’D) Sorry I only brought one, Dallas. Anyway, um, I was totally out of line the other day. I had a little touch of the “baby blues” and I think my hormones just got the better of me. But I have help now.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: I’m very pleased to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: And I understand about Jonah. Sometimes it’s just not the right fit.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: You'll find the right fit for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Public school. Free of charge, free of Jesus! She grins triumphantly. Laurie is not sure what to make o Marlo’s manic humor, but she smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, you guys have a great day.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: You too! Marlo exits cheerfully.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: (to Laurie) I would not eat that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo, Drew, Sarah and Jonah eat a home-cooked meal. Marl wears Mia in a sling and chats animatedly about the day’s events.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (rambling) ...so then I stopped by the Department of Education and they told me the public schools provide free occupational therapy for any kid who qualifies! You just have to get something called an I.E.P, but the evaluation for that is free too, and I already called Early Intervention to schedule it. So this could wind up being better for Jonah than St. Vitus ever was.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Wow. You’ve been really busy.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I’m just energized, I guess. Craig was right. Sometimes you just need an extra pair of hands.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: And this is so delicious I want to punch someone in the face. How did you make it? Marlo shrugs.  51.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It’s so easy to roast a chicken. You just stick some lemons in the cavity, salt, pepper, and you’re good to go.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Is the cavity the butt?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Gross, Sarah, no.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It’s just a big, gaping hole where the chicken’s guts used to be.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: That’s worse than a butt.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You’re right, Sarah, it’s murder. Drew laughs. And Marlo smiles, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s night again. Marlo cruises to the door in SLOW-MOTIO dreamy, pulling it open. There she is, as reliable and radiant as the sun: Tully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We begin a MONTAGE, so positive in tone it’s nearly ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC UP
dialogues.text: Marlo and Tully sit side by side on the couch, watching T Women on TCM. Marlo nurses Mia. She and Tully are deep in conversation, laughing and chatting. When Marlo finishes nursing, she rearranges her shirt. Bu instead of handing the baby back to Tully immediately, sh keeps talking, engrossed.  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different outfits, different night. Tully and Marlo make homemade BREAD together. Marlo wears Mia in the sling whi she and Tully talk and knead the dough. The clock on the microwave reads 1:05 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo cuts the loaf of FRESHLY BAKED BREAD and serves it Sarah and Jonah with butter and jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo fills out I.E.P. PAPERWORK for Jonah while Tully re a large REFERENCE BOOK called How to Advocate for Your Special Needs Child. Tully points out a passage to Marlo and they discuss. Mar reaches for a YELLOW MARKER and HIGHLIGHTS a sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s an unspecified time of night. Marlo climbs into bed to a sleeping Drew. She pulls the covers up to her chin a snuggles into the pillow, a slight smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo is getting ready for the day. She’s looking less an less like a zombie; her hair is brushed, and she actually a little color in her cheeks. She reaches into a MAKEUP POUCH and takes out a BLACK LIQ EYELINER. She hasn’t work it in years, but she leans forw and applies it in Tully’s signature cat-like style. It co surprisingly easily to her. She examines herself, satisfi INT. MARLO AND DREW’S HOUSE (DEN) - NIGHT Tully and Marlo sit with a pile of inexpensive BABY GIFTS that have been sent to Mia. We see Tully writing a THANK NOTE on stationery that says “MARLO MOREAU” at the mast. “Dear Aunt Lorene: Thank you for the...” Tully glances at the GIFT again. “,..glow worm toy for Mia. It is so cute! Love, Marlo.”  53. She adds the card to a pile. Marlo, who is also writing a note, smiles gratefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo enthusiastically kicks a SOCCER BALL to Sarah while sleeps contentedly in the stroller. INT. MARLO AND DREW’S HOUSE (BEDROOM) - NIGHT INTO DAY Marlo is sound asleep again. The room goes from DARK to L in time-lapse. Marlo rises, stretching, refreshed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo sipping her morning latte, takes a deep breath and composes a TEXT to her old friend VIOLET. “This is Marlo Moreau. Wanna be friends again?” Then, she types. “(I£ you'll have me.)” A moment. An ellipses. And then: “Welcome back to the land of the living.” Followed by: “Bitch.” Marlo chuckles to herself, relieved. EXT. CRAIG AND ELYSE’S HOUSE (ESTABLISHING) - DAY Craig and Elyse’s mansion looks even more impressive by d There are a bunch of PINK BALLOONS tied to the mailbox at end of the driveway. EXT. CRAIG AND ELYSE’S HOUSE (BACK YARD) - DAY It’s the perfect sunny spring day for GRETA’S BIRTHDAY PA Of course, Craig and Elyse have gone completely over the There’s a dessert table, pony rides, etc. A DRONE soars above the proceedings, taking video.  54. Jonah is playing with water balloons. Marlo is hanging ou a folding table while Mia sleeps in the car seat. Drew is a few yards away at the BAR. A costumed PRINCESS swishes past him with an armful of PARTY PROPS (wand, bag dress-up clothes, etc.)She accidentally drops her tambour Marlo watches as Drew bends over to help the princess pic her items. They chat for a moment. The princess is basica a rough-looking stripper in a ball gown, but Drew is clea charmed. Craig suddenly and conveniently appears next to Drew and joins the conversation. It’s obvious the two guys are bei extra “on” for the princess, who’s laughing. Marlo can’t but notice how the girly costume and wig affect the two m Drew notices Marlo watching with a wry expression and hea back over. Craig reluctantly follows. Marlo clocks Craig Drew's beers.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It’s 11 a.m.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I know. It’s oatmeal stout. Did you see Princess Hannah? She was a Miss Hawaiian Tropic finalist.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: How magical.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Greta looks happy. Greta does look happy as she and her friends, including Sarah, run up to Princess Hannah. Shasta, the nanny, foll after as always.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Greta should look happy. Look at all this shit. Our wedding at the Ritz wasn’t this nice. Elyse walks over, spanking Craig playfully on the butt.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Yes it was! She winks at Marlo.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marlo, you look awesome! For real.  55.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You’re not lying this time.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Ha ha. How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I’m really, really good. Thank you so much for the night nanny.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s been a game-changer. I mean, I can’t overstate-- Craig looks at them quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You called her?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah. I decided to stop being “Marlo the Martyr” and accept help. Seriously, I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Isn’t it nice to have some help and actually be able to enjoy your kids?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Where are your kids, Elyse? Taken aback, Elyse scans the yard.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Um... I don’t know. But I’m sure they’re having the best time. Right? I mean look at all this. She takes a sip of wine, embarrassed. Suddenly, Sarah appears, clinging to Marlo.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Hey, Sarah. What's up?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you go see what Princess Hannah’s doing?  56.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don’t think she’s a real princess.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Sure she is.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No. Her skin looks like an orange peel.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Sarah!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It’s orange and there’s like holes in it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Those are called pores.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yeah, she has big pores. Marlo pats Sarah’s shoulder with affection. INT. CRAIG AND ELYSE’S HOUSE (PLAYROOM) - DAY The party has moved into the PLAYROOM. Kids mill about, making a mess and eating pifiata candy. Marlo and Sarah a the front of the room, singing a KARAOKE DUET together. N both of their faces are painted as BUTTERFLIES. They’re d a shockingly good job at “Call Me Maybe.”

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hey, I just met you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: And this is crazy.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: So here's my number.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Call me maybe.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH AND MARLO
dialogues.text: Before you came into my life I missed you so bad. I missed you so bad. I missed you so, so bad.  57. Sarah and Marlo are dancing around, enjoying a rare momen pure mother-daughter whimsy. Drew watches his wife, surpr to see her being this outgoing. Marlo struts to the front of the room, doing a crazy danc solo, spanking her own ass and “riding the pony.” Craig and Elyse appear at Drew’s side.

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Marlo seems really... awake.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Ha ha, yeah, she’s got the pep back in her step, as our Nana used to say. I’m loving it. Craig seems pleased, but Drew doesn’t recognize this pers He looks slightly disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I mean, it’s actually kind of weir--

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Oh look, she’s doing the Nae Nae!

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELYSE
dialogues.text: Go Marlo! Go Marlo! Craig and Elyse are so entertained by “Fun Marlo” that Dr manages to suppress the nagging feeling of of concern and join the party, so to speak. He smiles tightly.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (pleased) There she is. INT. MARLO’S CAR — DAY Drew drives home. Jonah and Sarah are asleep in the back seat. Marlo is passed out in the passenger seat. She’s sweated off most of her butterfly makeup and looks slight deranged.  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully, having just arrived for her shift, drops her OVERSTUFFED BACKPACK on the floor of the kitchen and open the fridge like a hungry teenager. Marlo can’t help but s as she paws through the food.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: What’s that in the pitcher?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Oh, I made sangria since it’s getting warmer. It always reminds me of college.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You see? You are a homemaker.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Because I made sangria? People make sangria in prison toilets.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I know. It’s called “pruno.” May I have a glass? This request surprises Marlo, coming from her baby’s caregiver, but she

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Uh, sure. I guess I’1l have one too. That’s polite hostessing, right? Marlo gets two glasses out of the cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: A-1. Let’s take the baby outside and enjoy the evening.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Sure. EXT. MARLO AND DREW’S HOUSE (BACK YARD) - NIGHT Marlo and Drew’s back yard is small, weedy and unimpressi no Japanese soaking tub. But there are WHITE FAIRY LIGHTS strung from the house to the detached garage, and it’s co Tully and Marlo (accompanied by Mia) sit on an outdoor co side by side, sipping their sangria.  59.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Am I ever going to meet Drew?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Sure, let’s wake him up right now.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I mean, isn’t he curious about the person who’s ministering to his wife and baby every night?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: He’s curious. He asks about you. But he’s-- well, he’s not the most social guy. Like, I love him, but he’s a nerd. A real nerd, not like a postmodern nerd. He’s the kind of guy who went to high school wearing a trench coat and a hat and not even a little deodorant. Tully nods. MARLO (CONT’D) Anyway, he works all day and then he really does a lot with the kids when he gets home. Homework, the reading log, all of it. We make their lunches together. And then he just shuts down. He goes upstairs and puts on his little headset and then he’s just out.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Don’t you guys ever...

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Have sex? No. We haven’t had sex in months. Maybe close to a year. He does puts a sock on the door to warn me when he’s masturbating.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: That’s considerate.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Are you in a relationship?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I’m in several.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha. I was like you back in the day. I tried every horse on the carousel. And then I met Drew.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Which horse was Drew? Marlo tosses back the last of her drink.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Drew was the bench. She pours out more sangria for her and Tully.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: But you love him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah. Definitely. I chose the right person; I know that.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Then why don’t you have sex?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Well, I hold the baby all day. It’s me and her and it’s primal; we’re just like two gorillas at the zoo. Then nighttime rolls around, and I’m just supposed to switch gears and go, “Okay, now I’m sexy. Now my boobs are supposed to be sexual, instead of two bags of milk ina Canadian grocery store. It’s like-- did you ever play Tetris? When I was a kid I used to play Tetris for hours and hours. I was addicted. And when I'd go to bed, I’d close my eyes and I’d still see those stupid bricks falling. It’s like that now, except instead of bricks, it’s Mia. I go to bed and I just see Mia. I smell her. I feel her. I can’t turn it off.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Of course you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
