dialogues.text: I like Drew. I like what I know of him. And I want you guys to stay together.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Oh, I do too. I don’t want my kids to grow up like I did. I had three stepmothers, can you believe that? Krystal, Tricia, and Wei-Wei.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Then we need to fix this. Does Drew have any sexual fantasies? Marlo is taken aback by this frank query.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Well, I mean, I’ve seen his browser history. Pretty basic stuff. You know, girls from Florida with stars tattooed on their ribs. Tully knows Marlo is holding back information.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually... there is one thing. Drew worked at a diner when he was in high school. Washing dishes. And the waitresses, they all wore those little outfits, with the hat? He’s had a fantasy about it ever since.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: There’s a reason they call them the formative years.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah. So I actually bought a uniform a while back, thinking I would wear it and surprise him. But then I just never got around to it. And now my legs have veins, my tits have veins... my body’s a relief map of a war-torn country.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Do you still have it? The little uniform.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yes, but even if it fits, it would just be depressing. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You, on the other hand-- you could wear the shit out of it. She gives Tully an awkward once-over. Tully raises an eyebrow, inspired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo quickly tiptoes down the STAIRS holding a wadded of clothing. Tully sticks her HAND out of the bathroom, dres room style. Marlo hands her the dress, amused by the gamb

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Here. Never been worn.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: (behind the door) There’s your trouble. Marlo waits outside the bathroom. The door swings open. T does, in fact, look very cute.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Patty melt?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You should keep that. Wow, you have had zero children.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Do you think I should leave it on when we get upstairs, or take it off?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Upstairs? Tully smiles expectantly and squares her shoulders. MARLO (CONT’D) You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo opens the door a crack. Drew is sound asleep, curle on his side of the bed. The clock on the night stand read 12:10 AM. Marlo opens the door fully. Tully walks in behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Is this a Fifties diner? I want to be accurate to the period.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It’s just a regular diner.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Am I sassy?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Maybe just keep the dialogue to a minimum.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Okay. Tully nods and walks over to the bed. She gently wakes Dr

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: (groggy) Huh? Jonah?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Hi there. I don’t think we’ve met. Will you be dining in today? Marlo nods reassuringly. Drew, in shock, just stares at Tully. Tully climbs on top of Drew effortlessly.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you’re not familiar with our menu, I recommend the egg cream. Drew struggles, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: What the hell, Marlo?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Drew. This is for you. Just go with it. Tully begins KISSING Drew. Marlo walks to the side of the bed. Drew resists for another moment, then surrenders. Tu begins pulling up Drew’s T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: We also have a wonderful selection of pastries. And I’ve just put ona fresh pot of hot coffee.  64.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: (helpless) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (to Tully) I’11 tell you what he likes.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you show me? I’m just a trainee.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: All right. Drew eagerly pulls off his shirt. Tully pulls down his pa Marlo gingerly creeps onto the bed and kneels behind Tull She unzips Tully’s waitress uniform-- if it’s possible to so tenderly, she does. She looks into Drew's eyes over Tully’s shoulder. He gaze back at her with LOVE AND GRATITUDE in his eyes, acceptin the gift without further question. INT. DREW AND MARLO’S HOUSE (KITCHEN) - MORNING The next morning, over COFFEE. They can barely make eye contact. Drew clears his throat. While embarrassed, he al looks like the proverbial cat who ate the canary.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Should we talk about last night?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: We don’t have to.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: That was pretty kinky. Where did the costume come from?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Just a uniform supply place. I was really nervous you wouldn't be up for it.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I was afraid you’d think I was crazy.  65.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Why haven’t we ever done that before?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It’s not like the opportunity ever presented itself... Hi, Jo-Jo! Before she can finish explaining herself, Jonah prances i the room in his pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: I had a dream about a camel. Marlo pulls him onto her lap.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: A camel! Were you in the desert?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: No, I was in my house.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: That’s so silly. You want pancakes?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Let’s see if we can make Mickey Mouse.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: But the last time we tried that, he only had one ear.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Nope, this is a two-ear day. I can feel it. Drew stares at his wife admiringly, lovingly as she and J head to the refrigerator for eggs and milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A running trail. Marlo, with earbuds in her ears, is read for her first workout since giving birth. She wears a spo tank and sweats. She starts JOGGING with a slow gait. There’s another RUNNER up ahead, a college girl with a ponytail, a perfect ass, and perfect running skills. Marlo runs faster. Soon, she’s gaining on the woman.  66. Determined, Marlo speeds up. She keeps running, her cheeks red. She’s pushing herself the point of exhaustion, running like the T-1000. We see Sarah riding her bike nearby. She pauses, watching mom fly by. She looks both impressed and confused. Marlo finally PASSES the girl. She veers off the path and practically collapses against a tree. She’s panting, red- faced. The girl slows up as she approaches.

dialogues.speaker: RUNNER GIRL
dialogues.text: You okay? Reveal Marlo, panting and red-faced, with two huge WET SP spreading over her breasts. Marlo gives the girl the thumbs up. Her head drops betwee her legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s late. The time on the microwave reads 9:59. Marlo is reading a book called “Parenting the Out-of-Sync Child.” She hears the familiar KNOCK on the door and puts down he book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully enters, looking subtly different. Her usual T-shirt been replaced with a cute “going out” top, and her sneake have been traded in for lace-up boots. She wrings her han apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Marlo, I’m really sorry to do this, but can I ask you a huge favor?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Of course. I mean, you’ve done so much for me. What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I need a night off. Like really bad.  67.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: No problem. You’ve been coming here every night for weeks. Just let me know when.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (surprised) Oh. Sure. You know, you could have just called me. You didn’t have to come here.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Well, that’s the thing. I want you to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Out. To the city. Tully’s energy is manic. Her eyes sparkle.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: The city-city?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Yeah. New York. Big Apple. City that never sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: To do what?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Fun stuff. Go to a bar. Dance. Marlo laughs at the utter absurdity of the idea.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Who’s going to take care of Mia?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know. It’s almost as though there’s another responsible adult at this address. Named Drew.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: But what if she-- Tully won’t even let Marlo finish a sentence.  68.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Mia’s been sleeping through the night for the last week. Drew won't even know we're gone.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: God, I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Drew goes into Manhattan every single day.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: For work. I can’t, Tully. You go out and have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I can’t have a good time without you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You know, I feel like I've been very useful around here. In many regards. And I don’t think this is an unreasonable request. I don’t have a lot of friends my own age, due to the unusual nature of this job, and I just need to get out. And P.S.-- you do too! You can’t be a good mom without adequate self- care.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I don’t know if getting shit- wrecked in Manhattan qualifies as “self-care.”

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Okay. You're right. (then) We'll go to Brooklyn. Her smile is irresistible. INT. MARLO’S CAR - NIGHT A newly made-up Marlo drives. She looks reasonably hip, having traded her sweatpants for jeans and a T-shirt. Tul rides shotgun, checking her makeup in a compact.  69.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I still think maybe we should have Uber-ed it.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I told you, I’1ll be the chauffeuse. I’1l have one or two drinks and then I’1l drive us home.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Why are you so nice to me? (dry) I mean, aside from the fact that you're being paid.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I think you and I both know that this is more than a transaction. Marlo chuckles uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’ve pretty much trusted you with everything.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I’ve trusted you, too. Thanks for not murdering me. Marlo snorts.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I need bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Bourbon’s my drink. Tully smiles and turns up the radio. Marlo’s worries star fade away as she becomes energized by their escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo’s Honda Fit crosses a bridge over a river that will take them out of Rye and toward the city.  70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo’s car cruises down Wyckoff Avenue in Bushwick. YOUN PEOPLE cross the street and converge on the corners, smok and talking. A GIRL wearing leg warmers makes out with he BOYFRIEND. Marlo becomes excited, restless, as she looks at the passing scene.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: This is my old neighborhood. I lived here for years.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Then this is where we should be.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It wasn’t always this nice. Look, there’s a bakery for dogs.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: What did it used to be?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: A bakery for humans.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yes. People ate flour in those times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo and Tully walk into a crowded, popular bar. Marlo l more radiant than we’ve ever seen her. Younger. It’s like tension in her face has disappeared for the first time in months. Tully strides up to the bar. Marlo hangs meekly beside he They somehow get IMMEDIATE SERVICE-- Tully has that power

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Hi. Two Makers, neat.

dialogues.speaker: HOT BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You want any water with that?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Do I look like I need a bath? The young BARTENDER grins at Tully.  71.

dialogues.speaker: HOT BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You got it, babe. The bartender disappears to fill the order. Marlo smiles wistfully at the flirtation.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: That guy is obsessed with you.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Actually, he was looking at you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. I have the sex appeal of a binder clip.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You look radiant tonight. Marlo looks at Tully with great affection.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Really? Go on.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: How long has it been since you had a girls’ night?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: A year or ten.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Do you have a lot of girlfriends?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Not anymore. She smiles uncomfortably, closing the subject. The barten pushes the drinks across the bar. MARLO (CONT’D) Thanks, babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully and Marlo settle in. Marlo looks around the room. PEOPLE HAVING FUN. Youth. Energy. She can’t help but smil This is exactly what she needed.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: This used to be a different bar. They must have taken it down to the studs. I hardly recognize it.  72.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Have you ever heard of the “Ship of Theseus” paradox?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yeah, in college, I think. Which one is that?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Let’s say you were to take a wooden ship and replace one plank every year. Eventually, the ship would be made up of entirely new planks and there would be nothing left of the original ship. So is it still the same ship? Or a new ship? A buzzed Marlo thinks about it very briefly.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: New ship.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Because it just is! Nothing’s the same. It’s a new ship, baby. Nouveau bateau. Her French accent is absurd as she takes a swig of bourbo

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Then what about people? When you look at your baby pictures, clearly you’re unrecognizable compared to now. But it’s you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: If every part of me has regenerated then I guess I’m not me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Well, humans can’t regenerate completely. There’s actually one part of us that doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What’s that, Encyclopedia Brown?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: The hearing cells in our ears. They can’t grow back. Once they’re dead, they’re dead.  73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re in a DIFFERENT BAR, where a ROCK N’ ROLL BAND rips through a raucous song. Music BLASTS, killing those ear c dead. Tully and Marlo dance wildly. Tully grabs Marlo’s hand. T twirl and spin. Marlo is drunk. She doesn’t care who’s watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thoroughly drunk Marlo and Tully settle into a more intimate bar for “just one more.” There’s a newfangled to screen JUKEBOX against the wall; a guy is plugging in som songs. Tully clocks it, excited.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I want to play something. Tully dashes off. Marlo checks out the cozy bar. A group PUNK GIRLS head to the bathroom en masse. Marlo stares at them longingly. Moments later, the song “Blue” by the Jayhawks begins playing; we recognize it as one of Marlo’s favorites from beginning of the movie. Tully returns to the booth.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Hey, this is one of my favorite songs!

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Mine too. That’s why I picked it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I used to listen to this with Violet all the time. (explaining) I lived with her, here in Bushwick, a long time ago. This was our record. (then, confused) How did you get it to play right away?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: It’s a secret.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You know what my daughter and her friends say? ” (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Secrets, secrets are no fun. Secrets, secrets hurt someone.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Well, if I tell you a secret, you have to tell me one of yours. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Sure. Why not?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: We‘ll do it at the same time. Count of three. Ready? Marlo nods.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One, two, three.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO TULLY
dialogues.text: I’m gay. I paid an extra fifty cents.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Wait, what did you say?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I paid an extra fifty cents. You can skip the line on these new jukeboxes if you pay just a little extra. I was feeling grandiose.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Thank you for sharing that, Tully.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Wasn’t it brave of me? Marlo sits back in the booth, closing her eyes, her head swimming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully helps Marlo walk down the street. Marlo is OBLITERA stumbling. Tully somehow seems perfectly sober.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Wait... wait... stop. You’re not going to drive, are you?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I’m fine. I promise.  75.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: That’s not possible. You went round for round with me. Let’s just leave the car here and take a cab back.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: But Drew will be angry. Marlo braces herself against a parking meter.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Drew doesn’t get angry. He just gets very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: And that’s worse than angry, isn’t it? Right. As always.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: This is the last thing you’re going to talk me into, Tully.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You're right. It is.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Oh, you’re quitting?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You knew this was temporary. Besides, I think it’s time for me to find another line of work.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: So what do you have lined up? I bet you have big plans. Your twenties are great. But then your thirties come around the corner like a garbage truck at 5 a.m. Yeah. You gotta think long-term. What are you going to do when that cute little ass drops and your feet grow half a size with each pregnancy, and the whole “free spirit” thing stops being charming and starts looking ugly?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I’m not afraid of the future.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You should be. I’m it.  76.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with that? You know what your problem is? You’re convinced you’re a failure, but you actually made your biggest dream come true.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I know how bad your childhood was. So now you’re giving your kids what you never had. That sameness you despise? That’s your gift to them. Waking up every day, doing the same things for them over and over even though it grinds you down. Yes, you are boring. Your marriage is boring, your house is boring, and that’s incredible. That’s the big dream you had when you were young. To grow up and be dull and constant and raise your kids in that circle of safety. You made it happen, Marlo. You are a steady and elegant mother. Day after day. Night after night.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (whispering) But I don’t feel safe. I feel scared.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m here for. To keep you safe, so you can doing your job. We can’t afford to lose you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Stop caring so much. You’re such a care lord.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You're a care lord. Marlo looks at Tully. She suddenly turns and runs across street to a rack of CITI BIKES. Tully watches, confused, Marlo drunkenly wrangles a bike.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marlo! Marlo rides off into the night at full speed.  77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo is riding as fast as she can toward her undisclosed destination. Tully comes up next to her on a second CitiB They both pedal like mad.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I need to go to my old place.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: But you don’t live there anymore. Marlo stops. Considers this. Takes off again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After riding for a few blocks, Marlo arrives at a big, ol industrial BRICK BUILDING. Panting and sweating, she hops the bike and drops it on the sidewalk. She approaches the door. There’s a large SECURITY KEYPAD for entry.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (to herself) Okay, what is this? Tully comes up next to her. MARLO (CONT’D) This didn’t used to be here. She drunkenly punches in a few numbers, muttering to hers

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unit 5... Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck. She repeatedly PUNCHES the key-pad in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Marlo, this is not your home. Marlo’s nose is pressed up to the glass.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: There’s a fucking lobby now? With furniture? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened to the guy who sleeps in the doorway? I used to step over that guy every morning to go to work. And he'd say “Good morning, Margo.” Every damn day. Me and Vi would bring hima sandwich sometimes. Where is he? Do you think he died?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. Let’s walk. Marlo pulls out her cell phone, desperately.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: She still lives here. I’m texting her. She’1l let us up. Do you like coke? She always has it. You know, you have not cleaned a kitchen until you’ve done it Bolivian- style. Marlo is frantically typing a TEXT MESSAGE. Tully tries t stop her, but she hits “send.” MARLO (CONT’D) I let her know we're here. She's going to like you a lot. Like, a lot.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: We have to go home. And I can’t leave without you, Marlo. I wish I could let you stay, and go up there, but there is no “there” anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yes there is. Look! She pounds the brick with her fist. Tully just looks at h sadly.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Come with me. Marlo’s tone turns accusing.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: This was your idea. Why did you bring me here in the first place?  79.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I was being selfish. We came too far out. I have to bring you home. Marlo rubs her BREASTS, wincing with discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Ow.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You're really full.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It hurts. I need Mia. I‘1l just go home and feed her. Marlo is massaging her sore breasts compulsively.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: No. Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (crying) I miss her.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You'll see her soon. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: She won’t the same tomorrow. That’s what you said. I don’t want her to grow!

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Yes, you do. Tully beckons to Marlo. Defeated, Marlo stumbles toward Tully. Tully takes her arm and leads her away from the building. Marlo lays her head on Tully’s shoulder and cri As they walk off into the night, we suddenly hear a VOICE the intercom. It sounds hoarse and disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello? Marlo, are you out there? But Tully and Marlo are already out of earshot, disappear into the night.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Marlo?  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully and a disheveled Marlo enter a SEEDY DIVE BAR they definitely don’t belong at. Tully guides Marlo toward the bathroom. The door SWINGS O A truly DISGUSTING DUDE is walking out. We can see even f this vantage point that it’s not an appealing place to de with the milk situation. But Marlo is desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully and Marlo enter the bathroom. It’s Trainspotting- filthy, with grafitti on the walls. Tully takes off her SWEATER and wets it in the sink under hot water.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I’m making a hot compress. It‘1ll feel like a little baby mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: This is really messed up.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: It’‘ll help get things going. She hands Marlo the makeshift compress. Marlo puts it on boob dutifully.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. Now milk yourself. Marlo stands over the toilet and starts massaging herself

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: It’s not working. (gagging) Oh God, it smells like Spam in here.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Think about Mia. Do you have a photo? That might help. She takes Marlo’s phone out of her purse and quickly pull Marlo’s PHOTOS. She scrolls through, looking for a photo Mia. We glimpse a lot of weird SELFIES of Marlo.  81.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why do you have so many pictures of yourself?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I keep thinking the next one will look different. Tully finds a photo of Mia and holds the phone in front o Marlo’s face. Someone BANGS on the door.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: One second!

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I’M PERFORMING A MIRACLE! (then) It won’t come out.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Let me. Do you mind? Marlo tacitly agrees. Tully begins kneading Marlo’s breas

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have to use a rolling motion. Marlo looks queasy. Tully rolls her hand back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See? It’s like a wave.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I think I’m going crazy. We hear a TRICKLING sound as Marlo’s milk finally lets do into the toilet bowl below.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: There we go. Marlo VOMITS. Tully holds back her hair. When Marlo comes for air, Tully is already there to gently wipe Marlo’s mo with a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now we’ll go home. INT. MARLO’S CAR - NIGHT Marlo is slumped in the front seat. Tully is in the drive seat. For the first time ever, she seems NERVOUS.  82.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Try to stay awake.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I’m so tired.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: I know. But I need you to stay with me. Let’s have a conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: All we do is converse. We’re like the people in a Spanish textbook. Maria and Julio, they never shut up. (then) What am I going to do without you?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You’re going to take care of yourself. You’re going to shower every day, nourish and exercise your body, and maybe even send yourself roses once in a while. Promise me you will.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (drifting off) That’s... so... corny...

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Look Marlo, it’s the bridge. They’re approaching the BRIDGE that takes them back to Ry

dialogues.speaker: TULLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look. You're going to be in a soft bed in your little house before you know it. Under the same roof with your three babies, cozy and crowded. That old carpeting in your bedroom. World’s weakest shower. Home.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Mmph.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: We're going home. Tully begins to lose control of the vehicle. First subtly and then, it’s beyond saving...  83. In an instant, the car CRASHES into a guard rail. Marlo’s eyes briefly open. Another car plows into them. Black wat Silence. A flashback to Marlo’s DREAM the first night she met Tull vision of the TULLY-MERMAID in the pool, her back turned, swimming away forever. SIRENS, the groan of a TOW TRUCK. The surprisingly mundan conversation of PARAMEDICS...

dialogues.speaker: PARAMEDIC 1, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can you pass me that gauze? Yeah, I didn’t even know they had pizza. But it wasn’t bad.

dialogues.speaker: PARAMEDIC 2, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Let’s get another blanket here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo lies asleep in a hospital bed. She’s BEAT UP. There cuts and lacerations on her face. She has a black eye, a broken arm, and her leg is in traction. Drew sits on a chair next to her bed, pale and gravely concerned. The room is silent. DR. SMYTHE, a middle-aged woman, knocks and enters.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SMYTHE
dialogues.text: Hi. You are Marlo’s husband?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: (rising) Yes. I’m Drew.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SMYTHE
dialogues.text: I’m Dr. Smythe. I’m on the psychiatric staff here. I’d like to talk to you about Marlo.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: DR. SMYTHE
dialogues.text: Not here. Let’s let her nap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew and Dr. Smythe are in an empty hospital room or offi away from where Marlo can hear them.  84.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SMYTHE
dialogues.text: Does she have a history of mental illness?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: No. Well, yeah. She had some depression after our son was born, five years ago. It was pretty bad.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SMYTHE
dialogues.text: When you say “bad”...

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: She didn’t want to hold him. She couldn’t look at him. She just wasn’t herself for months. She actually, well, she did try to-- (flustered) Just tell me what’s going on.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SMYTHE
dialogues.text: We think she’s experiencing something similar now, but on a more extreme scale. This is what we call “postpartum psychosis.” Drew is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Psychosis?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SMYTHE
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s a lot more serious than just depression. It’s characterized by hallucinations, delusions...

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: But she’s been amazing! She’s so different this time. Her brother got her a night nanny to help out, and she’s getting sleep...

dialogues.speaker: DR. SMYTHE
dialogues.text: Actually, we believe she’s suffering from extreme exhaustion and sleep deprivation.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Oh. How? (surprised) I didn’t know. She seemed better than she’s ever been. (thinking) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, there have been a couple of things that were out-of-character, but I just... I just can’t believe she would drive drunk like that. And she just disappeared without telling me. There was no one watching the baby!

dialogues.speaker: DR. SMYTHE
dialogues.text: Weren’t you home?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, but...

dialogues.speaker: DR. SMYTHE
dialogues.text: What about the night nanny?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I don’t know where she was. I don’t know anything about her; it was Marlo’s thing. Can I go back in there, please?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SMYTHE
dialogues.text: They actually need you to finish some of the paperwork at Admitting. Then we’ll reconvene.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlo lies in bed, woozy and dreamy. She stares at the TR next to her bed. Untouched food, a plastic pitches or wat There’s a KNOCK. She manages to turn and look at the door

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: (whisper) Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew walks up to the ADMITTING area, where a female EMPLO surrounded by files taps away on a computer.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Hi. Did you guys need some information on Marlo Moreau?  86.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: Moreau, yes. I have almost everything I need. Do you have your insurance card? Drew digs the card out of his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. He hands the card over. The employee begins typing rapidl her keyboard, and asking questions in the familiar, distracted tone of those who do such work.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: ..-And the patient’s date of birth?

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: (typing) ..-Last four digits of her social?

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: And her maiden name? Drew is distracted, checking his phone as he replies.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Tully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to Marlo’s hospital room swings open. It’s Tully uninjured. No worse for the wear. She smiles apologetical at Marlo.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Hey. You’re a little beat up.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You should see the river. Marlo’s voice is an exhausted croak. MARLO (CONT’D) I didn’t tell anyone. About you. They don’t even know you were there.  87.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: You can tell them if you want to. It’s okay. The people here will understand.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I don’t know if they will. Tully sits down on Marlo’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: We can’t see each other anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: This was supposed to be temporary anyway. A few weeks. Just until the smoke cleared.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What do I do now?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: What you’ve always done. And then you'll do it again. And they’11l grow, and you'll grow, and one day you’ll rest and you’1l wish you could do it all over.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: If I’m older, how are you wiser?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Because I have lots of time to think about stuff. Remember? She smiles and smooths Marlo’s hair back from her forehea Marlo takes Tully’s hand and holds it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Thank you for keeping me alive.

dialogues.speaker: TULLY
dialogues.text: Same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew is heading back to Marlo’s room. He passes Tully in hallway as they head in opposite directions. He doesn’t notice her. Of course.  88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew enters. He sees that Marlo is awake and stops in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Hi. Drew reaches out and touches Marlo’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Um. (choked up) I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Why are you sorry? Drew is trembling.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I let this happen to you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: You didn’t do anything. Drew starts crying.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I know. That’s the problem. I didn’t know what was happening at night! I was just overwhelmed, between the baby, and work, and it seemed like you were doing great.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I was doing great. (smiling) Wasn't I great?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Fuck that. I don’t need you to be great. I just need you to be you. We love you so much. I’m sorry if you want to run away. I do too. But I don’t, because I love us.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I love us too. (then) Am I in trouble?  89.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Yeah. You’re in trouble. Marlo nods, painfully. Drew lays his head on her chest. S touches him with her good hand.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who were you with last night?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Nobody. Tears slide down her cheeks. MARLO (CONT’D) But next time I want to be with you.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Yes. Let’s go out. Let’s talk. There’s still a world out there. We could go see it sometime. Even if it’s just for a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weeks have passed. Marlo walks down the hallway of her ho with a CANE. Her bruises have faded to yellow, but her ar still in a sling. She stops into Sarah’s room. Sarah is laboring over her homework, aS usual. Marlo leans over Sarah’s desk, murmur guidance, then tousles her hair. INT. MARLO AND DREW'S HOUSE (JONAH’S BEDROOM) - NIGHT Marlo moves on down the hallway to Jonah’s room. Jonah si patiently in his pajamas, awaiting his treatment as he do every night. Marlo is there to attend to him. She props h cane against the wall and limps toward him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Ready?  90. As in the beginning, we hear “Major Tom,” from Jonah’s Langley Schools Music Project album. Marlo reaches for Jonah’s WILBARGER BRUSH.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s start with your feet tonight. She begins sweeping the brush over the soles of his feet.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Mom, is this real? Marlo pauses.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Does it work? We do it every night but I’m not sure what it’s supposed to do. Marlo thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Well, honestly, I don’t know. Do you like when we do it?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: I like being by you. Marlo smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I like being by you too.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: And it feels nice, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Well, maybe that’s all that matters.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: But we can just be together. We don’t have to do the brush. I kind of don’t think it’s real.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: Okay. If you don’t think we need it, then I guess we'll stop. She puts the brush down and rests her chin in her hands.  gl. Jonah suddenly leans forward and puts his arms around her

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: I love you. The SONG ends.

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: I love you too. They’re still wrapped in an embrace.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Can you play the song again?

dialogues.speaker: MARLO
dialogues.text: The same one.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Yes, silly mommy. Always the same one. Marlo leans over to the CD player. She presses “play” on track again, starting the song. Then she presses “repeat,” ensuring that Jonah will hear as many times he wants. Jonah and Marlo rock back in forth in an embrace as Major counts down again, for the hundredth time, the thousandth
